page.description: Enables or disables a button on a toolbar.

discussion.p: The *[xb:<toolbar>.controlEnable()]* method sets that status of a button on a toolbar to either enabled or disabled. The toolbar is specified by the object pointer, <toolbar>.

If you want to control the state of buttons on system toolbars (i.e. toolbars that are opened automatically by a Form, Browse, Print Preview window), then you must first get a pointer to the system toolbar before you can use this method. Use the [Toolbar::get() function] to get a pointer to a toolbar whose name you know.

page.syntax: Current_State as L = <toolbar>.ControlEnable as L(index as N,flag as L)

argument.name: index
argument.description: Index specifies which button on the toolbar that is set. An Index value of 1 specifies the first button on the toolbar.

argument.name: flag
argument.description: .T. = Enable the button, .F. = Disable the button

section.note: A toolbar's name can be determined by undocking the toolbar so that it is floating, and checking the title that appears in the toolbar title bar.

section.title: Example
section.example:
dim tbar as P tbar = toolbar::open("My Own Toolbar") tbar.controlenable(3, .T.)
'The following disables the 3 rd control on the default toolbar in 'Form View '----------------------------------------------------------------- tbar = toolbar::get("Form View") tbar.controlenable(3,.f.)
